instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message: Hello. So I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that suffered medium to major liquid damage. It was drawing 9mA, PP3V42 was 0 volts, PPBUS was 0 volts. I had the replace several components in the 3V42 area and I still have to replace most of if not all of the components in the area next to the LCD connector as well as the LCD connector. The SMC area looks ok, no signs of liquid but some resistors have that dull look to them. Well since I was not getting anything from PP3V42 and no light I decide to replace all of the components in that area. I now get 2.7V on PP3V42 but no green light. PPBUS is now 8.18v so I checked <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and it is at the 2.7V mentioned. So I assume my SMC is not turning on. Any ideas why PP3V42 is 2.7v vs the 3.42? Also, would you fix the other areas before getting PP3V42 properly working? I'll look at it more tomorrow I just thought I would ask on here first. This is just a project board for me to practice on so it is not super critical if I get it to work I just thought it would be neat to get it running because of the bad condition it was in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message:
I would reball SMC if corrosion is so advanced.
Check <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>/96 and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages.

Post diode mode (red probe at grounde) at 3V42.
Don't forget to check the value once SMC is removed too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message: Still working on this one. I am going to do as you reccomend and will post back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message:
diode mode is .296
<RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>/96 ARE 1.25V
<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> are all ok vs working board except 3.42v & voltage on pin 3. on working board it is like 7.2v. this one is like 5.9v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message:
Be sure <CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR> is OK.
Check all traces in the area.
You can play with <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>/96 values to adjust output voltage for 3V42 rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message: I am missing the end of the probe point that goes to pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR>. Is that just a test point? or does it need to be connected to anything else?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message: I did pull <CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR> and tested it to be ok. I will play with the resistir values

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message: I replaced <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> as well but as you can guess nothing changed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message:
1.25V at FB pins points to good <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> chip.
If all traces are good, you must play with Ra/Rb (<RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>/96) to adjust correct voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message: Ok, I will try that next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message: What is the threshold voltage to get the SMC to turn on? does it have to be exactly 3.4V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message:
SMC can work with lower voltage.
But it MUST start to work when power is stable.
That's the reason there is a reset circuit.
Reset threshold is the level which decides when SMC can really START.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Nightmare
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR> was reading 278k when pulled off the board. I replaced it with a 200k and now we have a working board! Other than putting on a new LCD connector we can call this one solved! Thanks again for the help.
